87.author: by Carl Nelson
87.appears_in: p. 13-17 in The Comics Journal, no. 248 (Nov. 2002).
notes: (Newswatch)

Report on the Small Press Expo (Sept. 6-7, 2002), with photographs of Art Spiegelman, Eddie Campbell, Frank Cho, David Collier, Batton Lash, Scott McCloud, Eric Reynolds, Gilbert Hernandez, Charle Burns, Roger Langridge and Denis Kitchen. Includes a list of the 2002 Ignatz Award winners, and an excerpt of a discussion about a new anthology called Orchid.

113.title: "Is there a Fantastical Genre of Comics?" "La Bande Dessin√©e Fantastique, Genre Impossible?"
113.author: Harry Morgan
113.appears_in: p. 91-99 in 9e art : Les Cahiers du Mus√©e de la Bande Dessin√©e, no. 4 (Jan. 1999).
notes: Begins: "Le fantastique, le vrai, est-il concevable dans un m√©dium vou√© √† la figuration, de surcro√Æt consid√©r√© comme populaire, voire destin√© √† l'enfance? De Breccia √† B√©zian, des EC Comics aux mangas, cette question traverse tout l'histoire de la bande dessin√©e."

English summary (from p. 143): "Is there a Fantastical Genre of Comics? Comics are obliged to be figurative; this does not predispose them to foster pure fantasy which relies on upheaval of reference points and certainties. Harry Morgan examines this limitation and constructs a typology of the fantastical, from EC Comics to the manga."
Includes illustrations and bibliographical references.

163.heading: Isaac le Pirate--Miscellanea.
163.title: "Pirates!"
163.author: Evariste Blanchet
163.appears_in: p. 100-105 in 9e Art : Les Cahiers du Mus√©e de la Bande Dessin√©e, no. 8 (Jan. 2003).
notes: Begins: "Les pirates d√©vastent les syst√®mes informatiques les mieux verrouill√©s, r√¥dent dans nos rues ins√©curis√©es (d'o√π la n√©cessit√© d'un plan 'Vigipirates') et abordent la culture avec, au printemps dernier, un salon du livre alternatif baptis√© 'Litt√©ratures Pirates', √† l'initiative des √©ditions Amok. Omnipr√©sents, ils n'en finissent pas de voguer dans notre imaginaire. Des pirates de tout sort, de toute √©poque et de tout lieu ont √©galement sillonn√© la bande dessin√©e."

English summary (from p. 151): "Pirates! If Barbe-Rouge by Charler and Hubinon represents the classic reference for pirate stories in French-Belgian comics, it is interesting to compare it, as Evariste Blanchet does, with recent creations such as Petrus Barbyg√®re (by Sfar and Dubois), Kaarib (by Calvi and Krassinsky), and of course the startling Isaac the Pirate (by Christopher Blain), which is full of surprising characters, among which stands out that of Alice, a magnificent portrait of a woman."

183.heading: Isabella, Queen.
183.title: "The Graveyard of Cathedrals"
183.author: Andreas ; J
183.appears_in: -M. & R. Lofficier, translation. 61 p. in The Graveyard of Cathedrals ; Starlight (New York : Nantier Beall Minoustchine, 1990).
notes: Translation of: La Cimeti√®re de Cath√©drales.

Summary: Professor Wallace de Wolff has found an early nineteenth-century painting of a gothic cathedral in a tropical rainforest, and curiosity leads him to learn of a group of renegade church architects called the Chavesians. The Chavesians had run afoul of the Inquisition, and were exiled to the New World by Queen Isabella, just a few years after Columbus's first voyage. After wandering in the wilderness for awhile, they found a spot in the Amazon jungle and began building cathedrals. Professor De Wolff, still only suspecting much of this, mounts an expedition to the Amazon which includes his son, Sidney, and his assistant, Fay McKee. Meanwhile, on another world, we find that at the end of the previous album Rork had teleported into a situation that has caused a cosmic imbalance, and the aliens decide they have to send him back. Rork lands, almost dead, in the company of the expedition just as they are being attacked by Indians. His presence saves the explorers, and they nurse him back to health. Rork is sensitive to forces coming from the cathedrals, and soon leads them there. An ancient madman tries to chase them away, and Rork identifies him as the evil force he felt. They find another man chained, and he seems to be the good force. Sidney de Wolff dies in a struggle with the madman at the center of a maze. They find another 500-year-old man, named Vosta, and release him from chains. Vosta tells the story of the colony. Rork tells Vosta that they'll meet again in a year, at Rork's house. The company breaks up, and on the way north Rork learns that Sidney's skeleton is inside the body of Vosta. In a wordless epilog Rork gets a message written in the language of the undersea civilization, and starts walking into a desert.
